Rinconete y Cortadillo

Digital Edition

The "Novelas ejemplares", or "Exemplary Novels", by Miguel de Cervantes are composed of twelve novellas, written in the short story style established in Italy, and best evidenced in the work of Boccaccio. However, Cervantes is an original writer who did not merely imitate a well-established literary model. Rather, he emulated it: alongside the more traditional, 'idealistic' tales, Cervantes also honed a new style, which critics have termed 'realistic'. "Rinconete y Cortadillo" is a supreme example of this innovative short story style.

By combining Harry Sieber's critical edition of "Rinconete y Cortadillo" in Spanish with an English translation, this digital edition aims to provide a new level of accessibility to Cervantes' enrapturing tale of theivery and faux-piety in the streets and brotherhoods of seventeenth-century Seville. Furthermore, these texts are presented alongside facsimile images of pages of the 1613 editio princeps, printed by Juan de la Cuesta in Madrid, and digitised as part of the Biblioteca Nacional de España's Biblioteca Digital Hispánica project (available here).

By complementing the digital edition with Spatial Humanities and Distant Reading analyses, this project aims to provide illuminating insight into the structure and style of the text.

"Y así, te digo otra vez, lector amable, que destas novelas que te ofrezco, en ningún modo podrás hacer pepitoria, porque no tienen pies, ni cabeza, ni entrañas, ni cosa que les parezca; quiero decir que los requiebros amorosos que en algunas hallarás, son tan honestos, y tan medidos con la razón y discurso cristiano, que no podrán mover a mal pensamiento al descuidado o cuidadoso que las leyere. Heles dado nombre de ejemplares, y si bien lo miras, no hay ninguna de quien no se pueda sacar algún ejemplo provechoso; y si no fuera por no alargar este sujeto, quizá te mostrara el sabroso y honesto fruto que se podría sacar, así de todas juntas como de cada una de por sí."

-Miguel de Cervantes, Prólogo al lector, "Novelas ejemplares"

"I assure you then, dear reader, that you can by no means make a fricassee of these tales which I here present to you, for they have neither legs, head, bowels, nor anything of the sort; I mean that the amorous intrigues you will find in some of them, are so decorous, so measured, and so conformable to reason and Christian propriety, that they are incapable of exciting any impure thoughts in him who reads them with or without caution. I have called them exemplary, because if you rightly consider them, there is not one of them from which you may not draw some useful example; and were I not afraid of being too prolix, I might show you what savoury and wholesome fruit might be extracted from them, collectively and severally."

-Miguel de Cervantes, Prologue to the Reader, "Exemplary Novels"
